- - - EXAMINATION
Sir, can you state your name for the record, please.
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: Brandon Chesney.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Mr. Chesney, my name is John Kaplan. I'm going to be taking your deposition. Have you ever had your deposition taken before?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: I have not.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: It would be a question-and-answer session in front of a court reporter where you were asked questions by an attorney under oath?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I kind of summarized what it is.  It's a question-and-answer session in front of a court reporter.  You're under oath.  The court reporter's job is to take down everything that's said in the room, but she can only taken down the spoken word. In response to a question, it's okay if you make a gesture, nod your head, shrug your shoulders, but you also have to say something.
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The court reporter can only take down one person speaking at a time.  I would ask that you let me finish my entire question before you respond, and I'll do my best not the interrupt your response with the next question, okay?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That's even if you anticipate what I'm going to ask you.  Let me ask it.
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Another reason is, even if you anticipate or think you know what I'm going to ask you, you might actually be incorrect, so let me ask the entire question, okay?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm looking for your best recollection of events, not a guess.  If I ask you a question and you don't know the answer or you don't remember, just tell me that you don't know or you don't remember, okay?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I don't think you're going to be here all that long, but if for any reason you want to take a break, just say so.  We'll take a break. The only thing I would ask is that, if there is a question pending when you want to take a break, that you respond to that question, okay?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You are represented by counsel here at this deposition.  During the course of the deposition, you might hear your lawyer say objection, object to the form, or something else. If your lawyer says something, just stop, and your lawyer and I will discuss and hopefully resolve or work out any issue that might come up.  Then your lawyer will given you an instruction, okay?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: If you don't hear a question that I ask you, tell me.  I'll repeat it.  If you don't understand what it is that I'm asking you, tell me, and I'll rephrase the question. Do you understand those instructions?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: I do.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: If you respond to a question, I'm going to assume you heard and understand it. It's very important that you say something if you do not hear or understand me.
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How old are you, sir?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: Are you employed at the present time?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: I am.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What do you do for a living?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: I do HR consulting, human resources consulting.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Who do you currently work for?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: A company called Facility Support Company.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You consult for them?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I forgot to tell you.  Sometimes we say uh-uh and uh-huh.  We all understand what you're saying, but it's my understanding it's spelled the same way.  When we look at the transcript, we're not going to know what you were saying.  If you do that, I'm going to say is that a yes, is that a no.
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are you self-employed?  Are you an independent contractor?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: Not an independent contractor.  I just consult.  I consult through a third-party company.  I do human resources consulting for a third-party company.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are you an employee of that third-party company?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What is that third-party company?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: It's called Facility Support Company.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you recall being involved in a motor vehicle accident on April 30th of 2017?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: I do.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you recall where that accident occurred?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: It was on Harbison Avenue.  I recall Harbison Avenue.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you recall approximately what time of day the accident occurred?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: I do not, I'm sorry.  I think it was around 7:00 p.m., between 7:00 and 8:00 p.m.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: At that time, was it dark out?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: I believe so, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you recall what the weather conditions were like?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: I do not.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You said it was on Harbison Avenue. Are you able to give me some idea where on Harbison Avenue?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: Harbison and Cheltenham would be, I believe, the cross street.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did the accident actually occur at an intersection?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: Feet before the intersection, I believe.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How many?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: I don't recall.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Another instruction I forgot to give you is there might be questions that call for some kind of measurement; time, distance, speed, something of that nature.  If you're able to give an exact response, please do so. If you can't but you feel that you're able to estimate or approximate, you are allowed to do so.  Just let me know that you're estimating or approximating.
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: With that instruction in mind, you are unable to estimate or approximate how far you were from the intersection with Cheltenham Avenue when the accident occurred?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: I don't have an exact estimation.  I could estimate it was maybe one block away, within the block of my left-hand turn to Cheltenham Avenue.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Where were you coming from?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: I was coming from center city Philadelphia.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: If the accident had not occurred, where were you intending to go?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: Home.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was it your intention that when you reached Cheltenham Avenue you were going to make a left-hand turn?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Harbison Avenue, as you approach the intersection with Cheltenham Avenue, is it a one-way or two-way street?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: It's a two way, and then both are two-way streets.  The left-hand turn is a two-way street, and Harbison Avenue is a two-way street.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I think what I asked you is Harbison Avenue a two-way street?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: Correct, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How many lanes are there to drive in on Harbison Avenue as you approach Cheltenham?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: Two.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: A total of four?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Two heading in the direction you're going and two heading in the opposite direction?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The vehicle that you were driving, what was the year, make, and model?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: 2004 Nissan Maxima.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was that your vehicle?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was it in good working order?  What I mean by that is, were the brakes, headlights, steering, horn, all working properly as far as you know?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: As far as I know.  I know I did have a donut on the vehicle.  There was a donut.  I had jut gotten a flat prior to that accident. I had AAA come out and change my tire, and then I proceeded on my way home.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You had actually had a flat tire right before the accident?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: Correct, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I know you said you were going home when the accident occurred. Did you have to be at home at any particular time?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was there anybody waiting for you at home?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was there anybody with you in the vehicle at the time of the accident?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The intersection of Harbison and Cheltenham, is that controlled by a traffic light, sign, any other traffic control devices?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: A light.  It's controlled by a traffic light.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Now, you mentioned that you had a donut on your vehicle. Do you happen to recall which tire that would have been?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: I believe it was the front left.

text: As far as you know, did having a donut on the front left wheel of your vehicle contribute in any way to this accident?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: I'm not sure if that contributed to the accident.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Why don't you pick it up when you're on Harbison.  Tell me what happened.
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: I don't remember much because I believe I was concussed right as the accident happened.  I don't recall seeing the car in front of me.  I just don't remember much from the accident itself. I do recall just heading home and then the accident happened and I was just very disoriented.  I believe I may have hit my head and was concussed.  That's pretty much all I remember.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were you in the right-hand or left-hand lane when the accident occurred?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: I believe I was in the left-hand lane because I usually take the left-hand lane to get onto Cheltenham.  Again, I don't remember, so I shouldn't guess, I apologize.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: In the accident itself, do you recall that you struck a vehicle in front of you in the rear?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: Not at the moment, not at the present moment.  Again, I was disoriented.  After a few minutes, I realized things weren't -- I was incoherent.  After that, I pulled over to see what was what, to see what was going on. At that moment, I realized something wasn't right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I think the question was do you recall being in an accident.
speaker: MR. MANARA

text: Yes.  I apologize.

text: Where you struck a vehicle in front of you in the rear?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: Yes.  Not immediately, but, yes, shortly thereafter.

speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: Honestly, I really didn't know what happened, so I was just going to pay for it myself.  I was going to pay for my damage myself.  Then I did talk to the insurance company and we went through the details of the accident.

text: You did report it to your insurance company?
speaker: MR. KAPLAN

text: I did not report.  I believe someone saw my license plate.  I got out of the car to exchange information and that type of stuff, but the person I was trying to speak to would not speak to me.  At that point, I didn't know what was going on. Again, I pulled over to discuss what happened and that type of thing, and the person I spoke to just would not speak to me.
